bibl.title: Broderick v Haller. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: Territory of Washington 3d Judicial District Agust Term AD 1857
To the Hon F A Chenoweth one of the Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States for the territory of Washington.

The complainant Michael Broderick of Port Townsend in the conty of Jefferson would respectfully represent to your Honor for & on behalf of five men whose names are to your complainant unknown but to the best of his knowledge and belief are subjects of her Majesty Victoria Queen of Great Britan and late Mariners of Marines on board of her Mejesty ship Sotatile_ are now unlawfully restrained of there liberty at Port Townsend at the United States Military Port by order of Mayor George, Haller an officer of the Unites States army

That your complainant knowns of no cause or pretence of said restraint except the alleged charge of desertion on there part from from her Magesties ship Satelite_ while in the Harbor of Port Townsend that your complaint believes the restraint to be illegal and wihtought authority of law, that your complainant belives that the aforsaid five men did not desert said ship now being engaged in utany or that they were left on shore by the officers of said ship stated to your complainant would therfore pray your Honor and were assited by the aforesaid major George Haller after the departure of said ship Sotatile_ from the water of the United States

An issue of writ of Habias Corpus Commanding the aforesaid George Haller to have the afore said five men whose names are unknown to your complainant but whom your complainant belives to be subject of her Magesty Victoria Queen of Great Brittan and late Mariner Marines on board of her Magestys ship Sotatile_ before your Honor together with the cause of detention and your complainant will ever pray
Sworn to before me this 13th day of July 1857
Filed in my ofice in court and J.C. 13th day of July 1857 T. Crannay_ Dist Clerk
NO70 Ex Forth Five Men Habeas Corpus July 13 1857
